## MATHEMATICS

9709/22

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 395, 92]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 100, 603, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{p}(x) = ax^{3} - ax^{2} + ax + b,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), and that the remainder is 35 when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x - 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 174, 146, 192]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 174, 373, 192]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 175, 920, 192]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 816, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) and show that the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\) has exactly one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 732, 92]]<|/det|>
Sketch, on the same diagram, the graphs of \(y = |2x - 11|\) and \(y = 3x - 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 658, 146, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 658, 468, 676]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(|2x - 11| < 3x - 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 658, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula, based on the equation in (a), to find the value of \(a\) correct to 3 significant figures. Use an initial value of 1.7 and give the result of each iteration to 5 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 88, 665, 248]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 262, 566, 282]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with parametric equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 288, 641, 308]]<|/det|>
\[x = k\tan t,\qquad y = 3\sin 2t - 4\sin t,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 316, 892, 336]]<|/det|>
for \(0 < t < \frac{1}{2}\pi\). It is given that \(k\) is a positive constant. The curve crosses the \(x\)-axis at the point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 146, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 348, 698, 365]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\cos t\) at \(P\), giving your answer as an exact fraction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 348, 920, 365]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 148, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 72, 438, 102]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) in terms of \(k\) and \(\cos t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 522, 186, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 522, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
Given that the normal to the curve at \(P\) has gradient \(\frac{9}{10}\), find the value of \(k\), giving your answer as an exact fraction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 73, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
